prompt:
Am I in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not helping a student?
I teach first grade in a very rural, low-economic area.  The average household is right at or below the poverty line; the only exceptions are the professionals in our community.  

Every year I offer to tutor my students who are below level in reading and/or math.  I do this free of charge (in my district, charging money for tutoring your own students is a conflict of interest.).  The tutoring sessions last forty five minutes and start immediately after school.  School lets out at 2:40, we start our lesson @ 2:50.  I provide a snack for the students since lunch time was at 11:00 and kids don’t focus well when they are hungry.  I pay for the snacks myself.  

Anyway, I had a parent from another school contact me out of the blue.  I was tutoring her best friend’s daughter (one of my kiddos, remember) and she wanted to know if I’d also tutor her son.  She told me his reading level, which was abysmal, and I have a really hard time saying no to a child in need.  I told her the tutoring times and said that if she could get the child there in time I would help.  

Turns out, the child attends school in a different county approximately an hour’s drive away.  The school also dismisses thirty minutes later than we do.  Obviously Mom can’t get the student to me in time.  So she asks if I would wait and tutor her son separately.

This means the child would arrive around 4:15.  I get to work at 6:30 and by 4:15 I am simply out of energy.  Besides, I have to help my own son with his school work and that’s always a hassle.  It takes me 40 minutes to drive home, which would mean I’d get home about 5:45, depending on traffic.  

The going rate for reading tutors in this area is $30 bucks per hour.  I wanted compensation for my time, so I told her the cost would be $25 per session.  

She completely flipped out.  Called me all sorts of horrible names and made some very uncouth remarks about my teaching ability.  The one that hurt the most was that I didn’t care about the kids, I’m just in it for the money, etc.  She told me I was a disgrace to teaching and incredibly selfish, and that this kind of shit was why everyone hates public school teachers.

Her words are constantly replaying in my head.  I don’t think I am an asshole for asking for compensation, but am I the asshole for not tutoring her student?
"""

Am I in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (I am in the wrong) and B for No (I am not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is a first-grade teacher in a rural, low-income area. They offer free tutoring to their own students after school, providing snacks and using their own time. A parent from another school asked if the teacher could tutor her son, who is in a different county and school that ends later. The teacher initially said they could help if the child arrived on time but then, when it became clear that wasn't possible, suggested charging $25 per session. The parent got angry, accused the teacher of not caring and being selfish.

So, the question is whether the teacher is in the wrong for not helping the student and charging for the time. 

First, the teacher is already giving a lot of their own time and money by tutoring their own students for free. They can't tutor another child from a different school district after their own schedule. The parent approached them because the child is in need, but the logistical issues (different school, later dismissal, commute) make it impossible without adjusting the teacher's schedule significantly. 

The teacher offers to do it for a fee, which is reasonable since they're not getting paid for this extra work and they do have personal responsibilities. The parent's reaction seems harsh, especially considering the teacher is already going above and beyond for their own students. The teacher isn't obligated to help students outside their school or district, and charging for the time seems fair given the circumstances. 

The parent's accusations that the teacher is selfish or only in it for money are a bit unfair, especially since the teacher is volunteering their time for their own students. The teacher isn't in the wrong here because they're setting boundaries and trying to manage their own time and resources. They can't be expected to help everyone without support or compensation. So, the answer should be B.
